course.course_name: Mobile Revolutions: Markets, Politics, and Journalism
course.course_description: Introduces students to the theory and practice of mass mobile phone communication in the United States and globally. Drawing on case studies including Occupy Wall Street, the Arab Spring, the London protests of 2011, and this year's U.S. presidential election, the course focuses on how mobile phones have been put to use and what new possibilities and risks lie ahead. Students will be asked to participate in and lead discussions in a seminar-style class, develop an idea for an application, and write a paper on a case study of their choice. The course includes several guest speakers and field trips around New York City.

course.course_name: Paying For News: Journalistic Business Models in the 21st Century
course.course_description: The journalism industry has undergone tremendous changes in the last 15 years. As news has become increasingly available online, journalistic business models that relied heavily on advertising have suffered. However, this doesn't tell the whole story. This class will examine the many ways that news organizations have been and are financially supported, and invite discussion on the advantages and drawbacks of each type of funding source. The class will also investigate other factors besides funding that can determine a news organization's success or failure. No prerequisites are required.
